The date of the court verdict sentencing Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison.

keyTakeAways: A Slovak court sentenced Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024.
Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker and public activist, admitted to shooting Fico five times from a distance of just over one meter, wounding him seriously in the abdomen, hip, hand, and foot.
The court ruled that Cintula committed terrorism, not just a murder or attack on a public official, citing his intent to target the prime minister specifically.
Cintula claimed he wanted to stop Fico’s policies on Ukraine, media, and culture, which he said damaged Slovak freedom and culture.
Fico, who has held power since 2006, attributes societal unrest to opposition criticism of his governance, while the opposition claims he has undermined democracy, media freedom, and transparency.
Cintula stated he saw the attack as a 'scream against fear' paralyzing society, and expressed intent to not kill but to hurt Fico.
The verdict has highlighted deep political and societal divisions in Slovakia, particularly between the populist Fico government and liberal, pro-EU opposition.
Cintula plans to appeal the sentence, calling it unjust, and his defense argued that not all attacks on officials constitute terrorism.
Fico has forgiven Cintula, despite ongoing health issues from the attack.
The case underscores tensions between political extremism, democratic norms, and public safety.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Slovak court has sentenced 72-year-old Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison for the attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024, during a public event in Handlova. Cintula, a former mine worker and public activist, admitted to shooting Fico five times from close range, injuring him severely. The court ruled that the attack constituted terrorism due to the specific targeting of a political leader, citing Cintula’s stated opposition to Fico’s policies on Ukraine, media, and cultural issues. While Cintula claimed he did not want to kill and described the act as a 'scream against fear,' the defense argued that not all attacks on officials are terrorism. Fico, who returned to power in 2023 and implemented policies criticized by the opposition, has forgiven Cintula. The verdict underscores deep political and societal divisions in Slovakia, with accusations of democratic erosion from the opposition and claims of political extremism from Fico’s side.
title: Slovakia court sentences suspect in attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico to 21 years
